DFedSat: Communication-Efficient and Robust Decentralized Federated Learning for
LEO Satellite Constellations

Minghao Yang, Jingjing Zhang, Shengyun Liu Minghao Yang and Jingjing Zhang are with the Department of Communication Science and Engineering, Fudan University, Shanghai, China. Shengyun Liu is with the School of Electronic, Information and Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China (e-mail: 23210720070@m.fudan.edu.cn, jingjingzhang@fudan.edu.cn, shengyun.liu@sjtu.edu.cn). (Corresponding author: Jingjing Zhang)
Abstract

Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites play a crucial role in the development of 6G mobile networks and space-air-ground integrated systems. Recent advancements in space technology have empowered LEO satellites with the capability to run AI applications. However, centralized approaches, where ground stations (GSs) act as servers and satellites as clients, often encounter slow convergence and inefficiencies due to intermittent connectivity between satellites and GSs. In contrast, decentralized federated learning (DFL) offers a promising alternative by facilitating direct communication between satellites (clients) via inter-satellite links (ISLs). However, inter-plane ISLs connecting satellites from different orbital planes are dynamic due to Doppler shifts and pointing limitations. This could impact model propagation and lead to slower convergence. To mitigate these issues, we propose DFedSat, a fully decentralized federated learning framework tailored for LEO satellites. DFedSat accelerates the training process by employing two adaptive mechanisms for intra-plane and inter-plane model aggregation, respectively. Furthermore, a self-compensation mechanism is integrated to enhance the robustness of inter-plane ISLs against transmission failure. Additionally, we derive the sublinear convergence rate for the non-convex case of DFedSat. Extensive experimental results demonstrate DFedSatâ€™s superiority over other DFL baselines regarding convergence rate, communication efficiency, and resilience to unreliable links.

Index Terms:
Decentralized federated learning, Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites, gossip, robustness.

I Introduction

Satellite communication technology is poised to become a key component of the future integrated air, space, and ground network, attracting significant interest from industry giants such as SpaceX and Amazon, as well as governmental organizations like ESA and NASA [1]. This enthusiasm has driven the deployment of numerous Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites. Advancements in satellite hardware have empowered LEO satellites with enhanced cameras, processors, and antennas, enabling the collection of extensive Earth imagery and sensor data [2, 3]. Leveraging machine learning (ML) techniques to analyze these large datasets can provide valuable insights for a wide range of applications, including urban planning, weather forecasting, climate change research, and disaster management [4, 5, 6].

However, the conventional methodology of transferring raw image data to a central server, such as a ground station (GS), for training a centralized ML model is impractical due to limited bandwidth and data privacy concerns. Federated learning (FL) offers a promising solution to these challenges [7]. Within the framework of FL, each client (satellite) independently updates ML models based on its local dataset, transmitting only model parameters in each iteration. This approach can significantly reduce bandwidth requirements while preserving data privacy.

Although research on satellite FL is still in its early stages, several studies have made significant progress. The traditional synchronous FL method, FedAvg [7], is applied to LEO constellations, demonstrating the benefits of combining satellite networks and FL [8]. However, the short, sporadic, and irregular communication windows between GS and satellites result in very slow convergence. To enhance the performance in satellite FL systems, researchers apply ISLs and clustering strategies [9, 10, 11, 12]. Additionally, High-Altitude Platforms (HAPs) are introduced as relays to facilitate faster convergence [13, 14]. To circumvent the limitations imposed by communication windows, asynchronous FL is applied to LEO constellations [15]. However, asynchronous FL encounters the issue of gradient staleness, where outdated gradients can significantly impair model convergence and overall performance [16]. Recent works attempt to mitigate this impact through rational scheduling [17], adjusting the weights of the outdated gradients[18, 19], optimizing the transmission delay to reduce the outdated gradients[20], and employing gradient compensation [21].

In contrast to centralized federated learning (CFL), decentralized federated learning (DFL) overcomes the limitations of the parameter-server structure [22]. The authors of [23] introduce refinements to DFL by employing multiple local iterations and quantization techniques to reduce communication costs, yielding promising convergence results, particularly in convex scenarios. More recent contributions, such as [24], propose methodologies like DFedSAM, which leverages gradient perturbation to generate local flat models via sharpness-aware minimization (SAM). This method achieves optimal results in current DFL-related work. In the decentralized satellite FL framework, model parameters are transmitted between satellites through inter-satellite links (ISLs). Research on decentralized satellite FL (DSFL) remains relatively sparse so far. Wu et al. propose DSFL [25], which uses intra-plane and inter-plane satellite links to accomplish model aggregation. It designs an inter-satellite routing algorithm to aggregate the model onto a specific satellite. Most recently, [26] proposes an offloading-assisted DSFL framework, aiming to speed up convergence by facilitating data sharing among satellites to counteract the effects of heterogeneous data distribution. However, they assume ideally that the transmission must be 100% successful.

In real satellite communication networks, inter-plane ISLs are usually unreliable due to two main factors:

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Doppler Shift: The rapid relative movement of satellites induces a significant, time-varying Doppler shift that impairs communication between satellites [27, 28, 29].

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Pointing Errors: Misalignment of the transceivers leads to pointing errors, resulting in additional performance degradation and even link failure [30, 31, 32].

The impact of such unreliability can result in the loss of the received signal, or even slow convergence rates and low communication efficiency. Therefore, for a more realistic study of DSFL, the instability of inter-plane ISLs must be considered. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to address this instability in DSFL. This study aims to bridge this gap by considering non-idealized ISLs in the LEO constellation and tailoring the DSFL framework for efficient and robust operation. To this end, we develop a robust and fully decentralized satellite FL framework tailored to LEO satellite networks, namely DFedSat. To address the issue of unreliable inter-plane transmission, DFedSat employs a robust model self-compensation mechanism to handle packet loss and transmission errors that may occur during model transmission.

Our main contributions are summarized as follows.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet We present DFedSat, a fully decentralized framework for satellite federated learning. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to address the instability of ISLs in decentralized satellite FL. The proposed framework enables distributed consensus of models by implementing two specialized mechanisms tailored for intra-plane and inter-plane model exchanges.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet To mitigate the adverse effects of unreliable inter-plane ISLs on the model transfer process, we introduce a self-compensation mechanism within our framework. This approach not only enhances the robustness of the inter-plane communication but also mitigates the overall communication overhead by reducing the need for retransmissions.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet We present the sublinear convergence rate for DFedSat in a non-convex setting under conditions of unreliable communication. Our findings indicate that DFedSat attains an asymptotic convergence rate comparable to that of the standard DFL algorithm in scenarios with perfect communication. This establishes the robustness and reliability of DFedSat, particularly in the presence of instabilities in inter-plane ISLs.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet We conduct extensive experiments to demonstrate the efficacy of DFedSat. Experimental results show that DFedSat exhibits higher performance and communication efficiency compared to the benchmark strategies. Furthermore, it demonstrates superior performance with high robustness under unreliable communication conditions.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II presents the system model for LEO Satellite Constellations and the framework of DFL. Section III elaborates on the proposed DFedSat algorithm, specifically designed for the LEO constellations. Section IV provides a convergence analysis of DFedSat. Numerical results are discussed in Section V, and conclusions are drawn in Section VI.

II System Model

In this section, we introduce the system model of the LEO system. This includes the architecture of the LEO Constellations, the satellite communication model, the satellite computing model within a DFL framework, and the ISL packet failure model.

II-A LEO Satellite Constellations

We consider a general LEO constellation consisting of Mğ‘€M planes, each with Kğ¾K satellites. The satellites are represented by the set ğ’©={s11,â€¦,s1â€‹K,â€¦,sMâ€‹1,â€¦,sMâ€‹K}ğ’©subscriptğ‘ 11â€¦subscriptğ‘ 1ğ¾â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘€1â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘€ğ¾\mathcal{N}=\{s_{11},...,s_{1K},...,s_{M1},...,s_{MK}\}, where each element smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk} denotes the kğ‘˜k-th satellite in the mğ‘šm-th plane. These satellites are evenly spaced by Ï€/Mğœ‹ğ‘€\pi/M radians within each plane, ensuring an equal number of satellites per plane.

Each LEO satellite is equipped with four antennas, two on the pitch axis and two on the roll axis, facilitating unicast satellite-to-satellite communication. This configuration provides four ISLs: two intra-plane ISLs for communication within the same orbital plane and two inter-plane ISLs for communication with satellites in different planes. Consequently, we can model the LEO satellite network as a 2D-torus undirected graph ğ’¢=(ğ’©,â„°)ğ’¢ğ’©â„°\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{N},\mathcal{E}), where we have |ğ’©|=Mâ€‹Kğ’©ğ‘€ğ¾|\mathcal{N}|=MK and â„°â„°\mathcal{E} represents the set of ISLs. An illustration of the LEO system is shown in Fig. 1.

II-B Satellite Communication Model

Compared to radio frequency communication, free-space optical communication is more suitable for interplanetary communication scenarios due to its higher data rate and stronger anti-jamming capabilities. The value of Î»ğœ†\lambda determines the convergence speed of the Markov chain introduced by the mixing matrix ğğ\mathbf{Q} to a stable state, which signifies distributed consensus.

II-D ISL Packet Failure Model

The inter-plane ISLs between satellites in different planes are highly unstable due to Doppler shifts and pointing failures. To quantify the impact of this instability on model transmission, we consider a packet failure model and define the probability of successful transmission as follows:

p:=â„™â€‹[SNR>Î³tâ€‹h],assignğ‘â„™delimited-[]SNRsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡â„p:=\mathbb{P}[\mathrm{SNR}>\gamma_{th}], (13)

where Î³tâ€‹hsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡â„\gamma_{th} is the link SNR threshold. To this end, each local model parameter ğ°mâ€‹kt,Isuperscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ¼\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t,I} is partitioned into dğ‘‘d packets and transmitted sequentially. We denote the model packets sequence as ğ°Ë‡âˆˆâ„dwdÃ—dË‡ğ°superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¤ğ‘‘ğ‘‘\check{\mathbf{w}}\in\mathbb{R}^{\frac{d_{w}}{d}\times d}. Following the modeling of [35], the process of randomly receiving model packets is represented by a Bernoulli random vector ğ¦âˆˆâ„dğ¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, with each element ğ¦â€‹[j]â€‹âˆ¼i.i.d.â€‹Bernoulliâ€‹(p),âˆ€jâˆˆ[1,2,â‹¯,d]\mathbf{m}[j]\overset{i.i.d.}{\sim}\text{Bernoulli}(p),\forall j\in[1,2,\cdots,d]. Specifically, for any jğ‘—j, we have

ğ¦â€‹[j]={1,with probabilityp,0,with probability1âˆ’p.ğ¦delimited-[]ğ‘—cases1with probabilityğ‘0with probability1ğ‘\mathbf{m}[j]=\begin{cases}{{1,\textrm{with probability}}}&p,\\ {{0,\textrm{with probability}}}&1-p.\\ \end{cases} (14)

As a result, the packets received by the receiver, which have been transmitted over inter-plane ISLs, can be represented as ğ¦âŠ™ğ°Ë‡direct-productğ¦Ë‡ğ°\mathbf{m}\odot\mathbf{\check{w}}.

III DFedSat

In this section, we introduce our proposed algorithm, DFedSat. The key innovation is the incorporation of a two-phase aggregation strategy in the model consensus stage to address the varying stability of ISLs, thereby enhancing the efficiency of the training process. Specifically, DFedSat employs an orbit reduce mechanism for intra-plane model synchronization. In contrast, for the volatile inter-plane ISLs, DFedSat applies a flexible gossip approach to manage model dissemination across different planes. This adaptive strategy not only facilitates model diffusion but also leverages the information gleaned from the preceding intra-plane synchronization, thereby accelerating model convergence.

Additionally, to mitigate the effects of packet failures due to the instability of inter-plane ISLs, DFedSat incorporates a model self-compensation mechanism during the inter-plane model dissemination phase. This feature leverages local parameters for adaptive self-compensation, significantly enhancing the systemâ€™s robustness.

III-A The design of DFedSat

The DFedSat procedure consists of two phases for each round tğ‘¡t: orbit computing and model consensus. The model consensus phase, guided by an adaptive aggregation mechanism, is further divided into two stages: intra-plane model synchronization, and inter-plane model dissemination. The pipeline of DFedSat is illustrated in Fig.Â 2, and the detailed steps are outlined in Algorithm 1. The specific procedures for each round tğ‘¡t in DFedSat are as follows.

1) Orbit Computing. Each satellite performs Iğ¼I local epochs via (10). In DFedSat, the updated model parameters serve as the starting point for the subsequent two-stage model consensus. Thus, we denote ğ°mâ€‹kt,Isubscriptsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¼ğ‘šğ‘˜\mathbf{w}^{t,I}_{mk} as ğ°mâ€‹kt+1/3subscriptsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡13ğ‘šğ‘˜\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{mk}, and hence represent the updated parameters as ğ–t+1/3=[ğ°11t+1/3,â€¦,ğ°1â€‹Kt+1/3,â€¦,ğ°Mâ€‹1t+1/3,â€¦,ğ°Mâ€‹Kt+1/3]âŠ¤superscriptğ–ğ‘¡13superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡1311â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡131ğ¾â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡13ğ‘€1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡13ğ‘€ğ¾top\mathbf{W}^{t+1/3}=[\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{11},...,\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{1K},...,\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{M1},...,\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{MK}]^{\top}.

2) Model Consensus. The entire phase encompasses intra-plane model synchronization using the ring all-reduce mechanism [36], referred to as orbit reduce, and inter-plane model dissemination employing a flexible gossip approach.

a) Intra-plane model synchronization. In this stage, each plane mğ‘šm with Kğ¾K satellites operates independently in a ring topology. Our objective is for each satellite smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk} to ultimately acquire the parameters from all other satellites in its plane mğ‘šm, thereby achieving model synchronization:

ğ°mâ€‹kt+2/3=âˆ‘j=1Kqmâ€‹k,mâ€‹jaâˆ—ğ°mâ€‹jt+1/3,âˆ€m,k,superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘¡13for-allğ‘šğ‘˜\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t+2/3}=\sum\limits_{j=1}^{K}q_{mk,mj}^{a}*\mathbf{w}_{mj}^{t+1/3},\forall m,k, (15)

where qmâ€‹k,mâ€‹ja=|ğ’Ÿ|mâ€‹j|ğ’Ÿ|m=|ğ’Ÿmâ€‹j|âˆ‘k=1K|ğ’Ÿmâ€‹k|superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘šsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘šğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘šğ‘˜q_{mk,mj}^{a}=\frac{|\mathcal{D}|_{mj}}{|\mathcal{D}|_{m}}=\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{mj}|}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}|\mathcal{D}_{mk}|} is the intra-plane mixing weight and |ğ’Ÿ|msubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š|\mathcal{D}|_{m} is the total number of training data samples held by all satellites in orbit mğ‘šm.

Orbit reduce begins with the scatter-reduce operation. Each satellite smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk} in plane mğ‘šm splits its local model parameter ğ°mâ€‹kt+1/3subscriptsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡13ğ‘šğ‘˜\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{mk} into Kğ¾K equally-sized segments and then performs Kâˆ’1ğ¾1K-1 communication iterations. Specifically, in each iteration, each satellite smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk} scatters one segment to the subsequent satellite while accumulating the segment received from the preceding one. After Kâˆ’1ğ¾1K-1 iterations, each satellite smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk} holds one unique segment of ğ°mâ€‹kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t+2/3}. Next, each satellite undergoes Kâˆ’1ğ¾1K-1 communication iterations of the all-gather operation. During this process, each satellite replaces its corresponding segment with the received segment instead of accumulating them. At the end, each satellite smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk} concatenates all segments to obtain the intra-plane synchronized model ğ°mâ€‹kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t+2/3}. An example of intra-plane model synchronization for K=3ğ¾3K=3 satellites via orbit reduce is illustrated in Fig. 3.

Remark 1. Note that each satellite smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk} performs a total of 2â€‹Kâˆ’22ğ¾22K-2 communication iterations. During each iteration, a satellite transmits one segment, which requires only 1K1ğ¾\frac{1}{K} of the time needed to transmit the entire model. Consequently, the total time, given by 2â€‹Kâˆ’2K2ğ¾2ğ¾\frac{2K-2}{K}, is bounded above by a constant independent of Kğ¾K. This implies that the total time required for intra-plane model synchronization remains constant regardless of the increasing scale of the constellation, demonstrating strong scalability.

III-B Model self-compensation for unreliable ISLs

We proceed to consider the general scenario that the exchanged local model parameters in the inter-plane model dissemination phase could fail due to link instability. To address this issue, DFedSat adopts a gossip self-compensation mechanism, where each satellite adaptively compensates for its neighborsâ€™ model parameters using corresponding parts of its local parameters. First, satellite snâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘˜s_{nk} partitions its intra-plane synchronized model parameters ğ°nâ€‹kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\mathbf{w}_{nk}^{t+2/3} into dğ‘‘d packets, denoted by ğ°Ë‡nâ€‹kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptË‡ğ°ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk}^{t+2/3}, and transmit them to satellite smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk}.

Then, satellite smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk} receives the model packets ğ°Ë‡nâ€‹kâ†’mâ€‹kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptË‡ğ°absentâ†’ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3} from satellite snâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘˜s_{nk} by unreliable inter-plane ISL:

ğ°Ë‡nâ€‹kâ†’mâ€‹kt+2/3=ğ¦nâ€‹kâ†’mâ€‹kt+2/3âŠ™ğ°Ë‡nâ€‹kt+2/3,superscriptsubscriptË‡ğ°absentâ†’ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23direct-productsuperscriptsubscriptğ¦absentâ†’ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23superscriptsubscriptË‡ğ°ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}=\mathbf{m}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}\odot\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk}^{t+2/3}, (20)

where ğ¦nâ€‹kâ†’mâ€‹kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptğ¦absentâ†’ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\mathbf{m}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3} is a Bernoulli random vector with each element adhering to the Bernoulli distribution with parameter pmâ€‹k,nâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘˜p_{mk,nk}. pmâ€‹k,nâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘˜p_{mk,nk} denotes the probability of successful transmission between satellite smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk} and snâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘˜s_{nk}. In the gossip self-compensation scheme, the receiver smâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜s_{mk} detects and sorts the received packets ğ°Ë‡nâ€‹kâ†’mâ€‹kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptË‡ğ°absentâ†’ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}, and then fills the corrupted or lost packets with its own model ğ°Ë‡mâ€‹kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptË‡ğ°ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\mathbf{\check{w}}_{mk}^{t+2/3}:

ğ°^nâ€‹kâ†’mâ€‹kt+2/3=ğ°Ë‡nâ€‹kâ†’mâ€‹kt+2/3+(Â¬ğ¦nâ€‹kâ†’mâ€‹kt+2/3)âŠ™ğ°Ë‡mâ€‹kt+2/3.superscriptsubscript^ğ°absentâ†’ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23superscriptsubscriptË‡ğ°absentâ†’ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23direct-productsuperscriptsubscriptğ¦absentâ†’ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23superscriptsubscriptË‡ğ°ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}=\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}+(\neg\mathbf{m}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3})\odot\mathbf{\check{w}}_{mk}^{t+2/3}. (21)

Fig. 5 is an illustration of model gossip self-compensation scheme of satellites among M=3ğ‘€3M=3 planes.

It is important to note that the compensated model ğ°^nâ€‹kâ†’mâ€‹kt+2/3superscriptsubscript^ğ°absentâ†’ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3} becomes stochastic due to the randomness of ğ¦nâ€‹kâ†’mâ€‹kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptğ¦absentâ†’ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘¡23\mathbf{m}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}. We can analyze this model diffusion process with a self-compensating mechanism from the perspective of expected values. With this rule, the expectation of orbit-personalized model vector ğ–t+1superscriptğ–ğ‘¡1\mathbf{W}^{t+1} can be calculated as:

ğ”¼â€‹{ğ–t+1}=ğ”¼â€‹{ğrCâ€‹ğ–t+2/3}=ğ”¼â€‹{ğrC}â€‹ğ–t+2/3,ğ”¼superscriptğ–ğ‘¡1ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptğğ‘Ÿğ¶superscriptğ–ğ‘¡23ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptğğ‘Ÿğ¶superscriptğ–ğ‘¡23\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{W}^{t+1}\}=\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}^{C}\mathbf{W}^{t+2/3}\}=\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}^{C}\}\mathbf{W}^{t+2/3}, (22)

where ğ”¼â€‹{ğr}ğ”¼subscriptğğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}\} is defined based on (20) and (21):

ğ”¼â€‹{ğr}:={qmâ€‹k,nâ€‹krâ€‹pmâ€‹k,nâ€‹k,mâ‰ n,1âˆ’âˆ‘k=1,nâ‰ mMqmâ€‹k,nâ€‹krâ€‹pmâ€‹k,nâ€‹k,m=n.assignğ”¼subscriptğğ‘Ÿcasessubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘˜1ğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘€subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘›\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}\}:=\left\{\begin{array}[]{l l}{{q^{r}_{mk,nk}p_{mk,nk},}}&{{m\not=n,}}\\ {{1-\displaystyle\sum_{k=1,n\neq m}^{M}q^{r}_{mk,nk}p_{mk,nk},}}&{{m=n.}}\end{array}\right. (23)

From (22), we can see that aggregating models via unreliable inter-plane ISLs is equivalent to reliable aggregation with the mixing matrix ğ”¼â€‹{ğr}ğ”¼subscriptğğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}\}.

Remark 2. In the presence of transmission failures, instead of relying on traditional retransmission mechanisms, we utilize the corresponding information from each satellite for compensation. As illustrated in Section V, this gossip self-compensation scheme effectively addresses packet failures, facilitating efficient convergence without significantly increasing overall communication overhead. Moreover, this approach is highly practical for satellite networks with limited resources.

IV Convergence Analysis

In this section, we present the convergence analysis of DFedSat for the general non-convex DFL setting. We begin by introducing the necessary assumptions.

Assumption 1. (L-smoothness). For each satellite smâ€‹kâˆˆğ’©subscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ’©s_{mk}\in\mathcal{N} and the parameter ğ°,ğ¯ğ°ğ¯\mathbf{w},\mathbf{v}, the function fmâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘šğ‘˜f_{mk} is differentiable and Lğ¿L-smooth, i.e.,

â€–âˆ‡fmâ€‹kâ€‹(ğ¯)âˆ’âˆ‡fmâ€‹kâ€‹(ğ°)â€–â‰¤Lâ€‹â€–ğ¯âˆ’ğ°â€–,âˆ€ğ¯,ğ°âˆˆâ„dw.formulae-sequencenormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ¯âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ°ğ¿normğ¯ğ°for-allğ¯ğ°superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¤\|\nabla f_{mk}(\mathbf{v})-\nabla f_{mk}(\mathbf{w})\|\leq L\|\mathbf{v-w}\|,\forall{\mathbf{v,w}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{w}}.

The first-order Lipschitz assumption is widely used in decentralized stochastic optimization works [37, 38, 39], reflecting the functionsâ€™ smoothness.

Assumption 2. (Uniform bounded local noise). For each satellite smâ€‹kâˆˆğ’©subscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ’©s_{mk}\in\mathcal{N} and all the parameter ğ°âˆˆâ„dwğ°superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¤\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{w}}, the uniform local variance bound is given as

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fmâ€‹kâ€‹(ğ°,Î¾)âˆ’âˆ‡fmâ€‹kâ€‹(ğ°)â€–â‰¤Ïƒ2.ğ”¼normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ°ğœ‰âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ°superscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f_{mk}(\mathbf{w},\xi)-\nabla f_{mk}(\mathbf{w})\|\leq\sigma^{2}.

We assume uniform bounded local noise, as done in many prior works [22],[40],[41]. The uniform local variance is used for the ease of analysis and it is straightforward to generalize to non-uniform cases.

Assumption 3. (Uniform bounded global noise). For each satellite smâ€‹kâˆˆğ’©subscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ’©s_{mk}\in\mathcal{N}, the uniform global variance bound is given as

1Mâ€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘m=1Mâˆ‘k=1Kâ€–âˆ‡fmâ€‹kâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ°)â€–â‰¤Î¶2.1ğ‘€ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ°âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ°superscriptğœ2\frac{1}{MK}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\|\nabla f_{mk}({\bf w})-\nabla f({\bf w})\|\leq\zeta^{2}.

The global variance measures the degree of non-IID data distributions (the heterogeneity of data sets), as used in [42], [43]. If the data across satellites are IID, then the upper bound of the global variance Î¶ğœ\zeta is 0.

Based on the assumptions above, we present the following theorem that characterizes the convergence of DFedSat.

Theorem 1. Let Assumptions 1, 2, and 3 hold. Choosing the stepsize Î·ğœ‚\eta satisfies 0<Î·<14â€‹Lâ€‹I0ğœ‚14ğ¿ğ¼0<\eta<\frac{1}{4LI}, then we have

â‰¤2â€‹fâ€‹(ğ°0Â¯)âˆ’2â€‹fâ€‹(ğ°TÂ¯)Tâ€‹(Î·â€‹Iâˆ’Î±)+Î²â€‹(Î·â€‹L2â€‹I+L+L2â€‹Î±(1âˆ’Î»aâ€‹Î»rC)2)Î·â€‹Iâˆ’Î±,absent2ğ‘“Â¯superscriptğ°02ğ‘“Â¯superscriptğ°ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğœ‚ğ¼ğ›¼ğ›½ğœ‚superscriptğ¿2ğ¼ğ¿superscriptğ¿2ğ›¼superscript1subscriptğœ†ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿğ¶2ğœ‚ğ¼ğ›¼\displaystyle\leq\frac{2f(\overline{\mathbf{w}^{0}})-2f(\overline{\mathbf{w}^{T}})}{T(\eta I-\alpha)}+\frac{\beta(\eta L^{2}I+L+\frac{L^{2}\alpha}{(1-\lambda_{a}\lambda_{r}^{C})^{2}})}{\eta I-\alpha}, (24)

where we have defined Î±=36â€‹Î·3â€‹L2â€‹I3âˆ’36â€‹Î·2â€‹Lâ€‹I2ğ›¼36superscriptğœ‚3superscriptğ¿2superscriptğ¼336superscriptğœ‚2ğ¿superscriptğ¼2\alpha=36\eta^{3}L^{2}I^{3}-36\eta^{2}LI^{2}, Î²=6â€‹Î·2â€‹I2â€‹Ïƒ2+18â€‹Î·2â€‹I2â€‹Î¶2ğ›½6superscriptğœ‚2superscriptğ¼2superscriptğœ218superscriptğœ‚2superscriptğ¼2superscriptğœ2\beta=6\eta^{2}I^{2}\sigma^{2}+18\eta^{2}I^{2}\zeta^{2}, Î»asubscriptğœ†ğ‘\lambda_{a} and Î»rsubscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\lambda_{r} are the second largest eigenvalue of ğasubscriptğğ‘\mathbf{Q}_{a} and ğ”¼â€‹{ğr}ğ”¼subscriptğğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}\} respectively.

Corollary 1. When we choose Î·=ğ’ªâ€‹(1/Lâ€‹Iâ€‹T)ğœ‚ğ’ª1ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘‡\eta=\mathcal{O}(1/LI\sqrt{T}), for a sufficiently large number Tğ‘‡T of training rounds, we can derive an explicit rate from Theorem 1 as follows.

Remark 3. Our algorithm DFedSat achieves a sub-linear convergence rate in the presence of unreliable links that is equivalent to the convergence rate achieved with reliable links in recent works [23, 24]. We observe that the convergence rate improves when the number Iğ¼I of local iterations increases. With a sufficiently large Iğ¼I, the local variance diminishes and does not undermine the convergence rate, as each satelliteâ€™s parameters approach a local minimizer. Moreover, the bound is dominated by ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2+Iâ€‹Î¶2(1âˆ’Î»aÎ»rC)2IT3/2))\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}+I\zeta^{2}}{(1-\lambda_{a}\lambda_{r}^{C})^{2}IT^{3/2})}\big{)} when Î»aâ€‹Î»rC>1âˆ’1Tsubscriptğœ†ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿğ¶11ğ‘‡\lambda_{a}\lambda_{r}^{C}>1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}. The convergence bound becomes tighter as Î»asubscriptğœ†ğ‘\lambda_{a} and Î»rsubscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\lambda_{r} decrease and Cğ¶C increases, which are validated in the next section.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we conduct a numerical comparison of the convergence performance of DFedSat with state-of-the-art algorithms, specifically those that adapt DSGD [22], DFedAvg [23], and DFedSAM [23] to the scenarios under study. Additionally, we analyze the robustness of these algorithms and investigate the impact of various system parameters.

V-A Experimental Settings

LEO Constellation Configurations. We examine a Walker-Delta constellation featuring Mâ€‹Kğ‘€ğ¾MK = 100 LEO satellites distributed across Mğ‘€M = 10 orbit planes. Satellites within each orbit are equally spaced, with each orbit positioned at an altitude of 604 km and an inclination angle of 143 degrees. The data is transmitted among satellites in 1.2 MB packets. To model packet corruption or loss, we employ randomly generated i.i.d. Bernoulli vectors. The maximum number of retransmissions for the baselines is set to 3. For readersâ€™ convenience, the pertinent parameters of the LEO constellation are summarized in Table I.

Datasets and Models. We conduct experiments on two commonly used datasets, CIFAR-10 [44] and CIFAR-100 [44], focusing on the FL task of image classification. The experiments consider both IID and non-IID data distributions. In the IID setting, the training dataset is randomly distributed across all satellites with equal local dataset sizes, and each satellite has all classes. In the non-IID setting, we employ the Dirichlet partition Dirâ€‹(Î±)Dirğ›¼{\rm Dir}(\alpha) with parameters Î±=0.6ğ›¼0.6\alpha=0.6 and Î±=0.3ğ›¼0.3\alpha=0.3 to represent the data heterogeneity. The backbone model used is ResNet-18, with an initial learning rate of 0.1 and a decay rate of 0.998 per communication round for all experiments. The weight decay is set to 0.001, and a mini-batch size of 64 with a momentum of 0.9 is used. The number of communication rounds is set to 300 for CIFAR-10 and 250 for CIFAR-100.

Baselines. The satellite scenario presents unique challenges compared to the standard decentralized federated learning framework for terrestrial applications. Satellites, acting as clients, typically operate under energy constraints, and communication links are often unstable, particularly for inter-plane ISLs. Given the scarcity of research on decentralized satellite systems, we explore the adaptation of canonical decentralized federated learning algorithms to the satellite scenarios.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet DSGD: DSGD performs one local update in parallel at each satellite during the local update stage.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet DFedAvg: This is the decentralized version of FedAvg. Each satellite performs multiple local updates before the communication takes place. The number Iğ¼I of the local epoch is set to 5.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet DFedSAM: Apart from multiple local updates, DFedSAM applies the Sharpness Awareness Minimization (SAM) optimizer at each satellite. The hyperparameter for the perturbation radius ÏğœŒ\rho of this SAM optimizer is set to 0.01, consistent with this in [23].

V-B Evaluation of DFedSatâ€™s Convergence Operation

Comparing DFedSat with the baselines. We evaluate the model performance of different algorithms from three key perspectives: convergence performance, communication efficiency, and ISL robustness. To ensure a fair comparison, we set the gossip round Cğ¶C to 1, matching the baseline settings.

V-B1 Convergence Performance

As illustrated in Fig. 6LABEL:sub@fig:a and LABEL:sub@fig:b, our proposed algorithm DFedSat outperforms the baselines in terms of both test accuracy and convergence rate in both IID and non-IID settings. The accuracy improvement is more pronounced as the level of heterogeneous data distribution increases (with Î±ğ›¼\alpha decreases from 0.6 to 0.3), demonstrating the effectiveness of DFedSat in addressing the statistical heterogeneity. Furthermore, DFedSat exhibits a more noticeable advantage in test accuracy on CIFAR-100 compared to CIFAR-10. This is attributed to DFedSatâ€™s two-phase model aggregation approach, where the inter-plane gossip step leverages intra-plane synchronized model information to enhance the performance of orbit-personalized models. This process effectively provides model information for non-adjacent satellites, further improving performance.

It is noteworthy that DFedAvg and DFedSAM show varying performance rankings on the two datasets under non-IID settings. Specifically, DFedAvg outperforms DFedSAM on CIFAR-10, while DFedSAM outperforms DFedAvg on CIFAR-100. This can be attributed to the SAM optimizer used in DFedSAM, which performs better with complex tasks and heterogeneous data. However, the SAM optimizer may incur more computational overhead as it requires computing the sharpness-aware gradient twice.

V-B2 Communication Efficiency

Fig. 7LABEL:sub@fig:comm-acc-a and LABEL:sub@fig:comm-acc-b illustrate the communication overhead of all algorithms when the test accuracy reaches the target accuracy of 80% (40%) on CIFAR-10 (CIFAR-100) in both IID and non-IID settings. As the heterogeneous data distribution level increases (with Î±ğ›¼\alpha decreases from 0.6 to 0.3), the communication overhead also increases. Notably, DFedSat demonstrates a significant advantage in communication efficiency compared to the three benchmarks. Specifically, the communication overhead of DFedSat is approximately 50% of that of DFedAvg and DFedSAM, and only 25% of that of DSGD. This advantage can be attributed to two main factors. First, the convergence speed of DFedSat is faster than the baselines due to the two-stage aggregation, leading to a tighter upper bound of convergence and requiring fewer rounds to reach the target test accuracy. Second, the communication overhead of a single round incurred by DFedSat is lower than the baselines because the model gossip self-compensation scheme effectively mitigates the extra communication overhead of packet retransmission caused by unreliable inter-plane ISLs.

Overall, from Fig. 7LABEL:sub@fig:comm-acc-a and LABEL:sub@fig:comm-acc-b, we can observe the superiority of the proposed model aggregation strategy over conventional strategies. Therefore, DFedSat emerges as a more communication-efficient algorithm while maintaining high accuracy.

V-B3 Unreliable ISL Robustness

Fig. 8LABEL:sub@fig:robust-a and LABEL:sub@fig:robust-b show the test accuracy of each algorithm as transmit power ranging from 0 dBm to 10 dBm. The experimental results show a negligible effect on the performance of DFedSat, whereas the baselines exhibit varying degrees of decrease in test accuracy as the transmit power decreases (implying a weakening of the ISL link stability), thus highlighting the superior robustness of DFedSat.

Fig. 8LABEL:sub@fig:robust-c and LABEL:sub@fig:robust-d show the communication overhead of each algorithm under different transmit power. It should be noted that the communication overhead of DSGD in 0 dBm was not recorded because it failed to reach the target accuracy in the case of poor link quality. Similar to test accuracy, the stability of the ISL link has a negligible effect on the communication overhead because of DFedSatâ€™s model gossip self-compensation mechanism. In contrast, the communication overhead of other baselines keeps increasing with decreasing link stability because of the repeated retransmission of erroneous or lost packets.

Impact of hype-parameters on DFedSat. We conduct an in-depth analysis of how the parameters such as the gossip round Cğ¶C and the number of planes Mğ‘€M in DFedSat influence convergence performance and communication efficiency.

V-B1 The impact of gossip round Cğ¶C

Fig. 9LABEL:sub@fig:r-a and LABEL:sub@fig:r-b illustrate the impact of gossip round Cğ¶C on test accuracy for the CIFAR-100 dataset under the non-IID setting (Î±=0.6ğ›¼0.6\alpha=0.6 and Î±=0.3ğ›¼0.3\alpha=0.3). It is observed that larger values of Cğ¶C can enhance performance, consistent with our theoretical findings. However, this may also lead to increased communication costs. A comparison between Fig. 9LABEL:sub@fig:r-a and Fig. 9LABEL:sub@fig:r-b reveals that the effect of increasing Cğ¶C is more pronounced in scenarios with higher data heterogeneity. This implies that employing a larger Cğ¶C value could serve as a beneficial strategy to effectively address the local consistency issue while striking a balance between performance and communication costs.

V-B2 The impact of constellation structure on Mğ‘€M

We maintain a total of 80 satellites and keep the other constellation parameters constant. As shown in Fig. 10LABEL:sub@fig:M-a, the test accuracy tends to increase as the number of planes Mğ‘€M decreases (resulting in a higher number of satellites per plane Nğ‘N). Intuitively, with fewer planes and a higher density of satellites per plane, each satellite obtains a more comprehensive partially aggregated model. This facilitates broader dissemination of model parameters among satellites in various planes, thereby enhancing overall performance. Remarkably, in a single-plane constellation, DFedSat obviates the need for the gossip dissemination step entirely. From a theoretical standpoint, as illustrated in Fig. 10LABEL:sub@fig:M-b, a smaller number of planes Mğ‘€M corresponds to a smaller value of Î»aâ€‹Î»rsubscriptğœ†ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\lambda_{a}\lambda_{r}, resulting in a tighter upper bound of convergence. Our experimental findings align with this theoretical perspective.

VI Conclusion

This paper has proposed DFedSat, a novel decentralized federated learning framework tailored to the LEO constellation. DFedSat has implemented two distinct mechanisms, orbit reduce and gossip dissemination, for intra-plane and inter-plane model exchanges, achieving efficient partial model aggregation. To address unreliable inter-plane model transmission, we have integrated the self-compensation mechanism into DFedSat, reducing communication costs and improving system robustness. Additionally, we have demonstrated the sublinear convergence rate for DFedSat in non-convex scenarios. Extensive experimental results have demonstrated that our algorithm performs competitively in terms of convergence performance, communication efficiency, and robustness to unreliable links, outperforming other DFL baselines
